data.title: Rescuezilla 2.0 Released With Support For Images Created By Clonezilla
data.meta_description: Rescuezilla 2.0 is the first 64-bit-only release. It is an easy-to-use disk imaging application that's fully compatible with Clonezilla.
data.text:
Rescuezilla 2.0 is the first 64-bit-only release. It is an easy-to-use disk imaging application that's fully compatible with Clonezilla.

Disk imaging makes a backup of your computer’s hard drive, which is managed as files stored on an external hard drive.

If your hard drive fails, you can restore your disk image, and within a few minutes, all your documents and settings will be restored to the same state they were in when the last snapshot was taken.

What’s Rescuezilla

Rescuezilla is a Ubuntu-based Linux distribution. It lets you perform backup, restore, and recovery actions, even if you aren’t able to boot into your regular operating system. It does not matter if you use Windows, Mac, or Linux.

Just download and write the ISO to a USB stick and reboot your machine. Your computer will load a complete mini operating system with a point-and-click user interface into your computer’s memory without writing any information to your hard drive.

What’s new in Rescuezilla 2.0

Here are the key changes that come with Rescuezilla 2.0:

Switched to creating backups in Clonezilla format for full interoperability with Clonezilla: Rescuezilla is now a drop-in replacement to Clonezilla. In other words, backups created using Clonezilla can be restored using Rescuezilla.

Backups created with Rescuezilla v2.0 cannot be restored using earlier versions of Rescuezilla. Backups created with older versions of Rescuezilla can still, of course, be restored with v2.0

Added ability to restore individual partitions, and optionally to not overwrite the partition table

Rewrote the Rescuezilla frontend in the Python3 programming language

Added backup/restore confirmation and summary pages, back button

Improved exit code handling and error messages, image selection

Added the ability to backup and restore SD card (mmcblk) devices

Disabled Linux time sync to prevent hardware clock modification

Added the ability to backup and restore software RAID (md) devices

Added filesystem-aware backup/restore of Linux Logical Volume Manager (LVM)

So is Rescuezilla a drop-in replacement to Clonezilla?

Yes. Since v2.0, Rescuezilla can restore backups created by Clonezilla, and backups created by Rescuezilla can be restored using Clonezilla.

Clonezilla will always have more options to tweak than Rescuezilla, but Rescuezilla can still restore images created with these options.

For example, in Clonezilla, you can go into “Expert mode” and select from 10 different compression algorithms and change the imaging tool from the default “partclone” to others like “partimage,” “ntfsclone,” or “dd.”

Rescuezilla might add some of these advanced configuration options. Still, until then, you can create your backups using Clonezilla with whatever advanced options you like and then restore them using Rescuezilla.

Bobby Borisov

Bobby, an editor-in-chief at Linuxiac, is a Linux professional with over 20 years of experience. With a strong focus on Linux and open-source software, he has worked as a Senior Linux System Administrator, Software Developer, and DevOps Engineer for small and large multinational companies.

Think You're an Ubuntu Expert? Let's Find Out!

Put your knowledge to the test in our lightning-fast Ubuntu quiz!

Ten questions to challenge yourself to see if you're a Linux legend or just a penguin in the making.

1 / 10

Ubuntu is an ancient African word that means:

United, we are stronger

Humanity to others

A god of wisdom worshipped by the Zulu tribe

Wrong! Ubuntu is a Southern African philosophy and term originating from South Africa and Zimbabwe. It is often translated as "I am because we are" or "humanity towards others." This concept emphasizes the interconnectedness of all people and the importance of community, compassion, and mutual support.

Correct! Ubuntu is a Southern African philosophy and term originating from South Africa and Zimbabwe. It is often translated as "I am because we are" or "humanity towards others." This concept emphasizes the interconnectedness of all people and the importance of community, compassion, and mutual support.

2 / 10

Who is the Ubuntu's founder?

Mark Shuttleworth

Richard Stallman

Linus Torvalds

Wrong! Ubuntu was founded (and funded) by Mark Shuttleworth, a South African entrepreneur and philanthropist.

Correct! Ubuntu was founded (and funded) by Mark Shuttleworth, a South African entrepreneur and philanthropist.

3 / 10

What year was the first official Ubuntu release?

2001

2002

2004

Wrong! Canonical released its first official version of the OS, Ubuntu 4.10, codenamed 'Warty Warthog' in October 2004.

Correct! Canonical released its first official version of the OS, Ubuntu 4.10, codenamed 'Warty Warthog' in October 2004.

4 / 10

What does the Ubuntu logo symbolize?

South African symbol representing unity

Circle of friends

Astronomical symbol for satellites of a star

Wrong! The Ubuntu logo, often called the "Circle of Friends," comprises three people holding hands. It signifies the strong sense of community and interconnectedness at the core of Ubuntu's philosophy.

Correct! The Ubuntu logo, often called the "Circle of Friends," comprises three people holding hands. It signifies the strong sense of community and interconnectedness at the core of Ubuntu's philosophy.

5 / 10

What package format does Ubuntu use for installing software?

RPM

DEB

TGZ

Wrong! DEB is the native and most common package format Ubuntu and other Debian-based Linux distributions use. It contains compiled binaries, libraries, configuration files, and metadata required to install and manage software on a Ubuntu system.

Correct! DEB is the native and most common package format Ubuntu and other Debian-based Linux distributions use. It contains compiled binaries, libraries, configuration files, and metadata required to install and manage software on a Ubuntu system.

6 / 10

When are Ubuntu's LTS versions released?

Every two years, in April

After two minor releases

Following the release of a major Debian version

Wrong! Ubuntu LTS (Long-Term Support) versions, known for their stability and extended support periods, are typically released every two years in April. These are popular for organizations and users who require a reliable and well-supported Ubuntu operating system.

Correct! Ubuntu LTS (Long-Term Support) versions, known for their stability and extended support periods, are typically released every two years in April. These are popular for organizations and users who require a reliable and well-supported Ubuntu operating system.

7 / 10

What is Unity?

An event-based replacement for the traditional init system used in Ubuntu

Ubuntu's display server

Desktop environment

Wrong! Unity was a desktop environment developed by Canonical and used in Ubuntu from version 11.04 (Natty Narwhal) to 17.04 (Zesty Zapus) as an alternative to the traditional GNOME 2 desktop environment.

Correct! Unity was a desktop environment developed by Canonical and used in Ubuntu from version 11.04 (Natty Narwhal) to 17.04 (Zesty Zapus) as an alternative to the traditional GNOME 2 desktop environment.

8 / 10

What are Ubuntu versions named after?

Animals

Constellations

Cartoons' characters

Wrong! Ubuntu versions are usually named using an alliterative adjective and an animal name, both starting with the same letter.

Correct! Ubuntu versions are usually named using an alliterative adjective and an animal name, both starting with the same letter.

9 / 10

What's Ubuntu Core?

An immutable version of Ubuntu for IoT and embedded systems

Module to Linux kernel used by Ubuntu

The main CI/CD system used in the development of Ubuntu

Wrong! Ubuntu Core is a minimalistic and immutable version explicitly designed for the Internet of Things (IoT) and embedded systems. It is based on Ubuntu and tailored for use in scenarios where reliability, security, and ease of maintenance are critical, relying on the Snap package and atomic transactional updates.

Correct! Ubuntu Core is a minimalistic and immutable version explicitly designed for the Internet of Things (IoT) and embedded systems. It is based on Ubuntu and tailored for use in scenarios where reliability, security, and ease of maintenance are critical, relying on the Snap package and atomic transactional updates.

10 / 10

Which Ubuntu version is Snap introduced?

Ubuntu 16.04 LTS (Xenial Xerus)

Ubuntu 18.04 LTS (Bionic Beaver)

Ubuntu 19.10 (Eoan Ermine)

Wrong! Snaps were developed by Canonical, the company behind Ubuntu, to package and distribute software focusing on security, sandboxing, and ease of installation and updates. They were officially introduced in Ubuntu 16.04 LTS, released in April 2016.

Correct! Snaps were developed by Canonical, the company behind Ubuntu, to package and distribute software focusing on security, sandboxing, and ease of installation and updates. They were officially introduced in Ubuntu 16.04 LTS, released in April 2016.

The average score is 68%
